page.title: 03Oxted Chalkpit.
page.content: The Chalkpits are in the hills called the{North Downs,}above Oxted. You can see it all white, cut out of the green grass, from a long way away. How long it has been there nobody is sure. One day the men dug out so much that the road, called Chalkpit Road collapsed, and they had to make a new road. When the chalk has been dug out it is taken by lorry to be loaded into big round kilns which are still there. The chalk is heated up to turn it into lime (in a big metal shed). The lime is soaked with water. Then it is dried, crushed up into powder, put into bags and taken away in lorries. In the old days it went by train which ran at the back of my Granny's garden. Long ago the Chalkpit and the School land were covered by sea.{Fossils}have been found in the Chalkpit and at School. By Tim Widdowson aged 6 years.
